div1.p: Carter discusses the seasonal presence and absence of mosquitoes, and the control of their breeding through the use of vegetation control, fish stocking, and maintenance of water level in ponds.

div1.head: Memorandum by Henry Rose Carter, [1923]
div1.p:
AnotherTwo problems short: easy, and it may be of considerable practical
importance is are.

(X) For each bench man in the locality in which he happens to be
in the late fall, to determine the last date at which Anopheles mosqui-
toes (quads. especially) are infective to men can be found in nature

(Y) Of scarcely less value is it to determine the date at which
the flight of the spring brood of quads begins.

The value of (x) is to determine when we can safely stop anti-breeding
larval methods at any place. Thus, Mayne determined that Anopheles infect-
ive to men were not found after--say--Nov. 15th, at Monroe, La. I have forgotten the exact date. now the mos-
xx now the mos- quito infective on Nov. 15th. must have received infection prior to Nov. 4th.
The egg from which she was evolved must have been deposited not less than
17 days before (16 days from egg to imago & 1 day for provocis to harden) (not later than Oct. 12th.). Very obviously then, we could
afford to stop anti-larval methods on that day, as eggs deposited after Oct 12
that would not produce imagoes that would infect this year. In point of
fact this allows for a large factor of safety, because in the interval from
November 4th. to November 15th. (at which data it is cold enough for the para-
site to die) we may be quite certain it is too cold to alow only 11 days
for its development in the mosquito (extrinsic incubation of malaria.). It
would take--say--25 to 30.

Similarly, between Oct. 12th. and Nov. 4th. the weather is too
cold to allow only 16 days for the cycle from egg to imago (I have allowed
one day for the hardening of the chitin so that the insect can feed on man).

I had, at that timein 1918 -it is now either in the, Central Office or
Mayne has it--a chart from the Agricultural Department: I have forgotten its
name, but it could well be called “A Chart of Iso-biological Phenomina Dates Dates,” in
which the curves show the places in the U. S. where certain biological phe-

nomena, such as I have just instanced, occur on the same dates.

Guided by this and allowing a fair factor of safety 18 I stopped my
anti-larval work on certain dates (different of course) thus determined, from Newport News to Houston, although Anopheles were
then in flight and breeding. There was some argument about it, but I knew
it was right. & I think I saved at least $150,000.00 and, taking the factors
of safety I did, with absolute safety.

In our records we have several determinations of the date of this
termination of infectivity, but a considerable number of others are needed to
serve as checks on the above map when used for control of mosquito production.

It is very little trouble to make this determination and I know you
can see how useful it may be.

(y) is advisable for the control of malaria on impounded water.
A. quad. bred in the ponds is, we think, the main factor in the production
of malaria from impounded water. (I will have rather and interesting little
piece to add to this, when I am able to sit up and write, on the role of
punctipennis.) Now our accepted--and a very efficient--method of prevent-
ing production in the large ponds is by holding the pond as high as pos-
sible during the season when quads. are not in flight,/ lowering it before
this flight begins, but as close to the time as may be. A pond thus handled--
(as is the case here now)--having an absolutely clean shore line and decent-
ly stocked with top-minnows gives no production.

You can see then how advisable it is to held the high water level as
close to the first flight as possible, but on no account to go into it.
We have in our Service literature, and a few notes of my own, these dates
for probably 25 or 30 different places and years. Thibault of Scott, Arkansas--
I think of Scott--gave me some data on it and everything he reports can be
relied on. One would have to fish it out from Service publications and re-
ports, but this is not hard to do and it gives us data which I judge will
prevent from 5,000 to 10,000 cases of malaria per annum by the ponds, and

(I will ask you to send this memorandum, as well as the original letter,)
(to the Central Office so as to determine whether; when and by whom it would)
(be taken up.)

Maxcy I would also ask--if your typewriter is functioning well--if you would
send me two copies for my own use. I want to send them to field men (one
to LePrince & Griffitts to get his criticism on it) and would ask both for your own cri-
ticism and for that of Dr. Fricks.

Sincerely
your friend
H. R. Carter
Asst. Surg. Gen'l
